awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Grant: Medical Technologies and Social Identities
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine the intersection of expertise, technology, and standards through a study of how surgeons and patients are using surgery to conform to and to redefine social norms. With advances in medical technologies and changing conceptions of the body, this study will document mechanisms of individual bodily modifications through elective medical procedures within a social-cultural context. This study will yield practical strategies for improving communication between patients and doctors and to explore the effects of markets and healthcare systems in multi-cultural contexts. 


The project proposes an ethnographic comparison of surgery in two multicultural communities. Through systematic observations of clinical encounters in cosmetic surgery clinics and interviews with surgeons and patients, the study will investigate how surgeons and patients are relating specific physical features to group identities and what the implications are for communities, healthcare systems and medical practices.  This study will extend theorization on classification and re-classification in (bio)medicine; and medical technologies and changing conceptions of the body in society.

por.por_cntn:
Physicians can shape and reinforce social identities in the practice of medicine, particularly racial and ethnic identities. In the elective subfield of cosmetic surgery, cosmetic surgeons have considerable discretion to interpret patient requests. Cosmetic surgery is a set of elective medical procedures in which patients pay out of pocket for modifications to their bodies which they believe will improve their appearance. These are procedures that are not medically necessary for survival. Thus, cosmetic surgeons and patients must come to an agreement about a match between patients' complaints or problems and surgical services. To illustrate desirable and achievable physical appearances, many cosmetic surgeons draw on existing social hierarchies. This project employs a comparative and transnational approach--focusing on two multicultural countries, the U.S. and Malaysia--to investigate how cosmetic surgeons decide on appropriate surgical looks.

With the support of the National Science Foundation, Social Science Research Council, and Northwestern University, the co-PI conducted interviews with cosmetic surgery providers and patients in the U.S. and Malaysia, as well as ethnographic observation of doctor-patient interactions in two clinics, content analysis of cosmetic surgery journal articles, and observation of plastic surgery professional meetings in the U.S. and around Asia. This research found that cosmetic surgeons consider race in evaluating the appropriateness and desirability of surgical "looks" requested by patients. Cosmetic surgeons balance the tension between race as an object of clinical knowledge and as an object of clinical intervention in the medical encounter. Surgeons generate and apply transnationally-circulating clinical knowledge based on racial categories, creating ethnically-specific looks instead of a universal look. In the doctor-patient consultation, use of race and ethnicity to describe clinical knowledge can appeal to patients in terms that matter to them and are clearly and widely recognizable. This helps cosmetic surgeons build rapport in the clinical encounter and develop strong relationships that encourage patients, their families, and friends to come back for future treatments.

Though much recent scholarship emphasizes standardizing forces in modern medicine, the case of cosmetic surgery highlights the persistence of variation, particularly in the absence of widely accepted clinical guidelines. In cosmetic surgery, variation provides surgeons with the opportunity to distinguish themselves from one another in a global market and appeal to patient choice. Invoking race as a criteria in ideal appearances allows cosmetic surgeons to maintain ambiguity while partially standardizing terms. That is, cosmetic surgeons in both the U.S. and Malaysia generated clinical knowledge about racial categories such as "Asian" without necessarily sharing a precise definition of the category. Use of racial categories in this way allowed surgeons to be inclusive and resonate with patients without necessarily pinning down the characteristics that correspond to a given racial classification.

Building on recent STS research on niche standardization and racial classification in science, this work suggests that the ambiguity of racial classification criteria can be productive in global fields of medicine. This research emphasizes the continuing association of race and phenotype, or physical appearance; for cosmetic surgeons, acknowledging social and cultural variation in racial meanings facilitates their access to and success in the transnational market. Furthermore, this work turns scholarly scrutiny from patients to cosmetic surgeons, highlighting their role as gatekeepers to ideal physical appearances. Finally, by examining the same medical specialty in the U.S. and Malaysia, this research incorporates a transnational dimension to trace clinical knowledge and practice beyond the West, focusing on multiple sites where expertise is enacted and exchanged.

This study contributes to our understanding of how social notions of race, ethnicity, gender and other identities are imbricated in contemporary medicine. The findings from this study provide insight into better mechanisms by which race and ethnicity might be taken into account in consumer-oriented medical practice. These findings can inform the making and communicating of treatment decisions and clinical knowledge. This work also contributes to contemporary social and political conversations about medical consumerism around the world. The co-PI has presented the findings at several academic conferences and has published them in leading journals across subfields, including Social Science & Medicine and Poetics. In addition, the co-PI has shared these findings directly with physicians, residents, and medical students through medical school course modules on race in medicine and public lectures.
